Dear Mr. Ziomkowski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

ALLEGATION:
On 2/02/22, youth was acting out. Staff members A and B at facility recorded
youth's behavior. Youth attempted to obtain the cell phones and Staff member A
pushed youth. Youth physically assaulted staff and was later transported to the
hospital for suicidal ideation and threatening others.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone, on 2/4/2022. She reported Youth A
informed her the incident began when he was in the gym “blowing off steam” and a staff
turned off the lights, so Youth A went outside to “shoot hoops”. Then he asked staff to go get
his coat to which they refused, triggering his anger outburst. Staff began to video record him
with their phones and he asked them to stop. Staff refused causing him to escalate,
resulting in Youth A attempting to grab one of their phones at which time staff pushed him.
Juvenile Justice Worker was interviewed via telephone, on 2/4/2022. He reported
learning of the incident from the facility and being surprised since Youth A had been doing
well except for the last three week. He believes there may have been a disruption in Youth
A’s relationship with a close relative that occurred about three weeks ago and resulted in his
acting out. He has no concerns with the treatment being provided by the facility and believes
the facility is keeping Youth A safe while providing the support he needs. The
communication from the facility is very helpful and constant.
Administrator was interviewed via telephone, on 2/4/2022 and face-to-face on 2/8/22 at
the facility. He reported being aware of the incident and reported Youth A is currently in the
hospital until Monday. He reported the facility does not have a policy of staff using their
phones to record youth’s behaviors but is willing to develop one. The facility was unaware of
the recording being a trigger but now that they do, steps will be taken to avoid this in the
future.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 2/8/2022. He reported being
upset over “family issues” lately and “lost control” of his emotions. The restraint was
appropriate, and no staff mistreated him during the incident. Youth A understands the
reason the lights were turned off in the gym and believes he needs to learn to control his
emotions better. Staff 2’s pushing him was “in self-defense and justified”. Youth A feels safe
at the facility and is being provided treatment to help him cope with his emotions.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 2/8/2022. He reported becoming
involved in the incident when Staff 2 informed him Youth A was outside destroying the
keyless entrance at the front door. Upon his reaching the area, Youth A had a shovel handle
and was beating the door and keyless entry pad. Staff 1 began to video record this behavior
for documentation because he knew the cameras mounted on the building did not pick up
this section. Youth A may have asked him to stop recording and once he realized his
recording was escalating Youth A, he stopped recording. Youth A was picking up pieces of
the shovel along with snow boards and sleds and striking staff with these items. Staff 1 also
reported never observing Staff 2 push Youth A because he was focused on picking up the
sharp pieces of the shovel, so Youth A didn’t use them as weapons. The restraint used with
Youth A was a standing two person (one staff securing each arm) that appeared, and they
3

were constantly talking to him to de-escalate Youth A.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 2/8/2022. He reported Youth A had
“acted out” earlier in the day and left the unit, going to the gym without permission. Youth A
began to shoot hoops in the gym before Staff 2 turned the lights off to “take away the fun of
being where he was not supposed to be”. Then Youth A went outside and began to throw
the basketball against the dining room windows where other youth were doing schoolwork.
Youth A was disrupting the unit and he began to smash the front door and keyless entry pad
with a broken shovel. Staff 2 also reported Staff 1 came onto campus and he asked him to
assist because Youth A was not de-escalating. Staff 2 has had a good relationship with
Youth A but was surprised when Youth A hit him several times and finally hit him in the leg
with a snow board. Staff 2 pushed Youth A to keep him from using the items on the ground
as weapons. Supervisor 1 came to assist and initiated a single person restraint with Youth A
because he was hitting staff.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 2/8/2022. She reported not
being present during the incident but talking to Youth A about the incident and viewing the
video recording. The pushing of Youth A appeared to be a defensive move because the
situation was very tense. Youth A was throwing things at staff. She also reported finding out
from Youth A after the incident how significant of a trigger video recording is to him. She will
be writing this in his treatment plan and discussing with the staff the importance of this
trigger in relation to his trauma responses.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 2/8/2022. He reported
having no history of disciplinary action taken against Staff 1 or Staff 2. He described both
staff as having excellent skills when working with the youth.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone, on 2/9/2022. He described the incident
outside with Youth A throwing items at Staff 2 in the same way described by Staff 1 and
Staff 2. Youth A was throwing sleds and snow boards at the staff and Supervisor 2 initiated
a single person restraint when Youth A attempted to punch Staff 2. Supervisor 2 did not
witness Staff 2 push Youth A during the incident but upon reviewing the video recording he
witnessed the push. He reported the push should not have occurred and is not part of the
techniques taught for behavior management.
Video Reviewed:
Video titled “VID_20220202_0831509862 with a date of 2/2/2022 and reviewed on 2/10/22.
This video provides a view of the front door to the facility. This video covers 40 seconds of
time. At the beginning of the recording, Youth A is viewed hitting the keyless entry to the
door with what appears to be the handle of a shovel. Youth A attempts to pry the keyless
entry off of the wall. Youth A turns and looks towards the camera before throwing the handle
in the direction of the camera which ends the recording.
Video titled “VID_2022-02-02_13-22-00_utc_39 Outside East entrance” with a date of
2/2/2022 and reviewed on 2/10/22. This video provides a similar view of Youth A at the door
but also captures Staff 1 and Staff 2 at the scene. Youth A is observed throwing items at
both Staff and both Staff are picking up broken pieces of items during this time. When
picking up the broken items, Youth A begins to throw plastic sleds at the staff and then picks
up a snowboard. He quickly walks towards the two staff and begins to strike them with the
snowboard. He dropped the snowboard and Staff 2 begins to walk towards him. Youth A is
4

backing up when Staff 2 pushes him backwards. Staff 2 then turns and walks back towards
the building
Documents Reviewed:
Safety Plan for Youth A dated 2/8/2022. This document outlines the emotions Youth A
struggles with and what triggers these emotions. Also listed is the behaviors others will see
when Youth A is triggered and what options Youth A can engage in to reduce his trauma
response. The last section lists how staff can engage Youth A to help him overcome the
distress he may be experiencing.
Updated Treatment Plan, dated 1/30/22 and covering a report period of 11/3/21 to 1/30/22.
This document states Youth A makes some progress but continues to struggle with
significant trauma issues which can cause his acting out at times.
Staff 2’s personnel file: There is no disciplinary record involving Staff 2. There is no
documentation that Staff 2 attended the scheduled CPI de-escalation and interventions
reviews in October 2021. Staff 2 did complete the refresher CPI trainings in 2020.
Incident Report, dated 2/2/2022 @ 8:48 AM involving Youth A. This document describes
the incident that was viewed on the video recording but does not mention Staff pushing
Youth A. This action by Staff 2 was missing from the report. This report was also written by
Supervisor 2 who acknowledged he did not observe the “push”.
Incident Report, dated 2/2/2022 @ 8:33 AM involving Youth A. This document also
describes the incident as described by the staff interviewed.
Residential Treatment Program Policies & Procedures Continuum of Interventions
dated 8/31/2020. This document outlines a goal of any intervention providing a positive
learning opportunity for the youth. It is also noted the intervention should be completed with
respect and concern for the youth.
Residential Treatment Program Policies & Procedures Physical Intervention dated
12/6/2021. This document indicates the “primary goal” an intervention is to de-escalate the
potential crisis and ensure the safety of the youth and others. This document also outlines
the type of restraints that are approved, and the restraint described in this incident is titled
as “Lower-level standing hold”. Staff training is outline and includes “Physical interventions
may only be undertaken by staff who have successfully completed the CPI
Residential Treatment Program Policies & Procedures De-escalation Techniques
dated 10/5/2020. This document indicates staff would downplay the challenge and not react
to the youth in a way that sets up a power struggle.
Bethany CPI approval letter dated January 12, 2018. This document indicates that staff
will receive at least 6 hours of annual training in this technique.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(2) At a minimum, the behavior management system shall
include all of the following:
5

(b) Positive intervention strategies to assist residents in
developing improved problem solving, self-management,
and social skills.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as evidence indicates
Staff 2 did not use appropriate behavior management
techniques when he pushed Youth A. This evidence is
supported by Staff 2 admitting to the push and review of video.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended to the facility that they develop a policy to
avoid staff recording youth on their phones. The facility reposed
by indicating they are in the process of writing such a policy.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Staff 2 did not have documentation of completing the annual CPI training as
required.
INVESTIGATION:
Staff 2’s personnel file: There is no documentation that Staff 2 attended the scheduled CPI
de-escalation and interventions reviews in October 2021. Staff 2 did complete the refresher
CPI trainings in 2020.
Residential Treatment Program Policies & Procedures Physical Intervention dated
12/6/2021. This document indicates the “primary goal” an intervention is to de-escalate the
potential crisis and ensure the safety of the youth and others. This document also outlines
the type of restraints that are approved, and the restraint described in this incident is titled
as “Lower-level standing hold”. Staff training is outline and includes “Physical interventions
may only be undertaken by staff who have successfully completed the CPI
Bethany CPI approval letter dated January 12, 2018. This document indicates that staff
will receive at least 6 hours of annual training in this CPI technique.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(5) An employee shall not participate in restraining a resident
or placing a resident in seclusion prior to receiving training on
those topics. The training model shall be approved, in writing,
by the department.
6

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as evidence indicates
Staff 2 did not complete his annual CPI training as required.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
It was recommended to the facility that they develop a system to
ensure staff are attending all required trainings and if not
attending a CPI training, then the staff should not be allowed to
engage in behavior management interventions with youth until
the training is completed.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective no change be made to the
license status of this child caring institution
